quoteFirst: At midnight twenty-one nautical miles had been paid out, and the angle of the cable with the horizon had been reduced considerably. At about half past three forty miles had gone, and nothing could be more perfect and regular than the working of everything, when suddenly, at
quoteLast: on Sunday, the 27th, Professor Thomson came on deck and reported a total break of continuity; that the cable, in fact, had parted, and as was believed at the time, from the Niagara. The Agamemnon was instantly stopped and the brakes applied to the machinery, in order that the cable paid out might be severed from the mass in the hold, and so enable Professor Thomson to discover by electrical tests at about what distance from the ship the fracture had taken place.
title: The Story of the Atlantic Cable
author: Bright, Charles, Sir, 1863-1937

quoteFirst: He looked at the clock.  It was
quoteLast: .  There was neither love nor desire in him and he would have liked to throw himself on the divan and sleep.  But he set his teeth and got to his feet.  He would go through it, play up, somehow.
title: Black Oxen
author: Atherton, Gertrude Franklin Horn, 1857-1948

quoteFirst: Grady returned home immediately, and his friends, who had prepared to greet him with a great reception, met him at the train only to learn that he was sick unto death. He was carried home suffering with pneumonia and at
quoteLast: to-day breathed his last. The nations will stop amid the Christmas festivities to lay upon the bier of the dead Southerner a wealth of tenderness and love.
title: Joel Chandler Harris' life of Henry W. Grady including his writings and speeches
author: Harris, Joel Chandler, 1848-1908 [Editor]

quoteLast: ," said her friend. "If it had been _past_ four, the four would have struck first. All _our_ clocks are what your clumsy human watchmakers call 'repeaters,' you see."
title: Fairies Afield
author: Molesworth, Mrs., 1839-1921; Hammond, Gertrude Demain, 1862-1952 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , and gave each and every one a good, hard “six licks at the dummy,” not hesitating to tell them how rotten they were――most of them――nor being at a loss for improving instructions. They resented his criticism more because it seemed to reflect on “Cocky” than for more personal reasons, but they didn’t harbor resentment long. “Steve” kept them too busy, maybe.
title: The Fighting Scrub
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Rahn, A. D. [Illustrator]

title: Apparitions and thought-transference: an examination of the evidence for telepathy

quoteFirst: I then went into my Closet and received Lord Melbourne there. He stayed with me till
quoteLast: . He seemed and said he was better. He has such an honest, frank, and yet gentle manner. He talks so quietly. I always feel peculiarly satisfied when I have talked with him.
title: The girlhood of Queen Victoria, vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Esher, Reginald Baliol Brett, Viscount, 1852-1930 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The front-line trench being deep and narrow with few fire-steps, it was difficult for the men to leave it, and realizing this, the company commanders began getting their troops out more than an hour before the time fixed for the attack. Zero hour was at
quoteLast: , and when it came the three assaulting companies of the 1st Regiment were already for the most part formed up in No Man’s Land.
title: The history of the South African forces in France
author: Buchan, John, 1875-1940
